text: A novel B cell - derived coactivator potentiates the activation of immunoglobulin promoters by octamer - binding transcription factors .

A novel B cell - restricted activity , required for high levels of octamer / Oct - dependent transcription from an immunoglobulin heavy chain ( IgH ) promoter , was detected in an in vitro system consisting of HeLa cell - derived extracts complemented with fractionated B cell nuclear proteins .
The factor responsible for this activity was designated Oct coactivator from B cells ( <extra_id_0> OCA-B <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) .

<extra_id_0> OCA-B <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> stimulates the transcription from an IgH promoter in conjunction with either <extra_id_0> Oct-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> or <extra_id_0> Oct-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> but shows no significant effect on the octamer / Oct - dependent transcription of the ubiquitously expressed histone H2B promoter and the transcription of <extra_id_0> USF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - and <extra_id_0> Sp1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - regulated promoters .

Taken together , our results suggest that <extra_id_0> OCA-B <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is a tissue - , promoter - , and factor - specific coactivator and that <extra_id_0> OCA-B <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> may be a major determinant for B cell - specific activation of immunoglobulin promoters .

In light of the evidence showing physical and functional interactions between Oct factors and <extra_id_0> OCA-B <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , we propose a mechanism of action for <extra_id_0> OCA-B <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and discuss the implications of <extra_id_0> OCA-B <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> for the transcriptional regulation of other tissue - specific promoters .
